awd_titl_txt: Synthetic Mimics of Avidin/Biotin for In-Situ Capture Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Nature often uses large biomolecules to capture and remove small targets from a mixture, in the same conceptual way that a fisherman employs a net to secure a fish. But biomolecules are relatively fragile which limits their utility, and there is a need for synthetic mimics that can capture specific targets, such as colored dyes, with high affinity and selectivity.  The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program supports Professor Bradley Smith of the University of Notre Dame to synthesize and study cylinder-shaped molecules that capture dyes on the surface of small beads. The dye coated beads can be easily detected using a cheap camera or even the naked eye.  They are potentially useful in environmental and biomedical applications.  The research activities provide rigorous student training in chemical synthesis and data analysis, as well as extensive experience in oral and written presentations. As part of a pedagogical project, Professor Smith and his students are upgrading the free internet workbook Organic Structure Elucidation by including a series of video answers to the problems. Free and unrestricted access to the video answers helps students who lack access to advanced educational resources or experienced instructors.

The project builds on a recent discovery that water soluble squaraine dyes with appended polyethylene glycol chains can be threaded with extremely high affinity by a water soluble tetralactam macrocycle containing anthracene side-walls. The term Synthavidin (synthetic avidin) is the generic name for this host/guest association system. The research develops the underlying synthetic and supramolecular chemistry to produce strong and rapid capture of highly fluorescent squaraine dyes in water, and complexation-induced changes in absorption and fluorescence properties. The work produces molecular design concepts that guide supramolecular researchers towards high affinity receptors for operation in water. The bead capture assay is endowed with two powerful attributes, namely, the capability to remove enzyme cleaved fluorescent dye from turbid media and the creation of amplified signal due to self-assembly of a hyperbranched fluorescent shell around the bead. The assay design is generalizable and can be expanded to include many types of cleavage enzymes.

por.por_cntn:
The project supported Professor Bradley Smith of the University of Notre Dame to prepare and study a series of host molecules that can capture a range of different molecular guests, especially fluorescent dyes and precious metals. The term Synthavidin (synthetic avidin) is the generic name for this host/guest association system. The research elucidated the underlying chemical design principles that enable high affinity and selective guest capture. As part of an ongoing pedagogical project, Professor Smith and his students upgraded the free internet workbook Organic Structure Elucidation by creating a series of video answers to the 64 problems and published them on the internet.

Intellectual Merit:

The dye capture work produced host molecules that captured highly fluorescent squaraine dyes in water, and induced changes in dye color and fluorescence intensity. The work demonstrated the functional advantage of using endofunctionalized macrocyclic hosts with inward directed hydrogen bonding residues that provide additional binding affinity and dye guest  selectivity. It is becoming apparent that this new class of host molecules can be employed broadly in science and engineering for tagging, purification, sensing, or catalysis. The gold capture work developed new molecules (tectons) that capture gold and related precious metals from organic and aqueous solutions and co-precipitate them as crystals. The work identified three dominant supramolecular interactions for co-crystal engineering; (a) hydrogen bonding between tecton and the gold halide anion, (b) electrostatic stacking of the gold center against the tecton's aromatic electrons, (c) very short hydrogen bonds within a proton-bridged-carbonyls motif. These interactions can now be incorporated into a robust molecular design paradigm that enables more accurate prediction of crystal packing motifs and tecton molecular conformations within the crystal lattice.

Broader Impact:

The use of Synthavidin technology to capture fluorescent dyes will likely be very useful as a tool within various analytical and biotechnology disciplines. This includes new types of fluorescence assays that measure the concentrations of biological metabolites or the products of enzyme action. Fluorescent dye capture inside cells can be used as an assay for measuring intracellular occupancy of a drug target. The gold capture and co-precipitation technology has obvious potential within gold mining or waste recycling, where new methods are needed to eliminate the use of toxic chemicals. In addition, careful solid-state engineering of gold-containing co-crystals, using the supramolecular rules uncovered by this research, will lead to new classes of composite materials that exhibit the many special chemical and physical properties of gold. The grant helped six chemistry graduate students (including four females) obtain their PhD. In addition, the grant supported the research effort of several undergraduates, and they have progressed to post-bachelor positions in science and allied health fields. The set of 64 video answers to the free internet workbook Organic Structure Elucidation is available as a YouTube channel. There are also optional video subtitles in English and French. The web-site and answer set is used regularly by hundreds of instructors and thousands of students around the world.
